replies.body:
But what if... they *are* evil? D:

It really depends on what you view as evil. The world is 51+ shades of grey, not black and white. Demacia isn't guilt-free :(

Except Garen. He's like a boy scout, the Superman of Demacia. And Lux is... well her old lore... let's just say she's a lot brighter than the rest of her faction >.>
Garen's been creeping on Kat since they met! :P

I think the creeping is mutual :3

I swear, their baby would be a beyblade or something.

someone sided with the templars in dragon age >.>
{{champion:17}} is an adorable death trap

To be clear: Demacia is EVIL. They are a ridiculously lawful, totalitarian dictatorship that is in many ways a military dictatorship.

Their main goal is to be stronger than Noxus and crush Noxus in direct combat...

So, odds are, those champions are some sort of LN or LE.

Remember, just cause someone looks like a paladin doesn't mean they aren't a blackguard in disguise.

"Remember, just cause someone looks like a paladin doesn't mean they aren't a blackguard in disguise."


http://giphy.com/gifs/racist-thats-4WHkXdDx8wjS0

Lore department has been pretty slackerly on portraying all of this, but it sounds like an extreme view that could easily be at least half-true.

The lore doesn't do the shades-of-gray department any favors when their enemy's name literally means "poison" and their dating profile includes Hobbies: Necromancy, Torture, Eating Babies.
Implying Necromancy is evil.

That's because it's difficult to kill people for good (as you can see from fact that the assassin is also the least good feeling member up there), but also difficult to win a League game with a full team of pacifists.

You have to allow some people who are fighting for justice, like {{champion:10}}, or trying to destroy evil, like {{champion:67}}, or defending the world from a danger more horrible than any number of tyrannical governments, like {{champion:38}}.

I dunno man, something about literally helping and protecting orphans makes me think Ekko is kind of a good guy, it doesn't get much more goodie two-shoes than protecting orphans, maybe they should have showed him petting a puppy so we can all be sure.

It's sort of unclear whether Kayle is Lawful Good or just Lawful Vindictive.  Similarly, Morgana is Chaotic Hot Topic.

Seems like there's this whole schtick where "Lawful" and "Good" are treated as being the same thing.  D&D intentionally treats them as independent variables... no wonder there was a big D&D scare in the 80s...

LN.  I'd imagine the government is extremely LN with a few LE tendencies.

Noxious doesn't even try to hide it, what with all the blood lust, chemical warfare, and *purple*

Pretty hard to be LN when the government is a hereditary military dictatorship (which is a very LE way to run a nation).

The people of Demacia might be largely LN, but the nation itself is a LE nation. (Which I guess is preferable to the insane CE of Noxus or the annoying LG tendencies of Ionia, but still not pleasant.)

i really don't see  {{champion:99}}  as a true demacian when i look at her champion judgment and {{champion:86}} has a thing for {{champion:55}} and i ship {{champion:133}} and {{champion:99}} with {{champion:91}}.{{champion:59}} can go die in a fire for all i care and {{champion:3}} is just annoying as fuck
Edit: first time my comment was downvoted so much is it just me or the galio mains really hate me lol

{{item:3070}} {{champion:3}} 
The Guardian was Unprepared for that.
im serious i would rather fight {{champion:429}}  or {{champion:67}}

why

why hate on Galio :(
To say he shits on magic damage would be an understatement.

likely due to his passive to covert MR into AP. I know I build him with lots of MR. sucks when I'm going support and can't protect well vs the enemy ADC, but during a team fight look out, here comes the gargoyle!  >:D

Really, just a few of Garen's lines were enough to convince me Demacia is more fascist monarchy than happy fantasy kingdom.  He wouldn't need to run around saying "What we do is right" without further justification if what they did was actually right.

That, and Lux's judgment.  Any nation-state where parents are delighted to _give_ both of their children to the military (regardless of the wishes of each child) is in pretty bad shape.
